According to the World Health Organization (WHO), as of February 59 2022, over 430 million people have been infected by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 60 Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), with almost 6 million confirmed deaths worldwide. Beyond 61 causing a prominent respiratory distress syndrome, COVID-19 is a systemic disease that affects 62 multiple organs. 1 Severe patients develop peripheral hyper-inflammation, coagulopathy, hypoxia, 63 hepatic dysfunction, sepsis, and acute kidney failure. Neurological disturbances are frequent in 64 COVID-19 patients and range from relatively mild symptoms, such as headache, anosmia, and 65 ageusia, to severe complications, including encephalopathy, stroke, delirium, and coma. 2-10 66 Follow-up studies carried out thus far indicate that a significant proportion of COVID-19 67 survivors experience persistent neuropsychological alterations, including anxiety, depression, and 68 cognitive impairment. 11-14 Both the manifestation of neurological symptoms during hospitalization 69 and the existence of prior neurological diseases, including dementia and neuropsychiatric 70 disorders, are associated with higher mortality by COVID-19. 10,14-17 Likewise, age, diabetes, and 71 maladaptive immune response are risk factors for COVID-19 severity and mortality. 18-20 However, 72 the mechanisms by which COVID-19 triggers neurological impairments and its long-term 73 consequences remain to be determined. We and others have shown that depression, dementia, and 74 diabetes share pathophysiological mechanisms leading to brain dysfunction in animal models. 21-75 24 Here, we examine the available evidence on brain infection by SARS-CoV-2, the induction of 76 systemic inflammation, coagulopathy, and blood-brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction as possible 77 mechanisms underlying neurological impairments in COVID-19. In some cases, neurological sequelae may result from irreversible damage 175 and neuronal death triggered by pathogens. 71 Alternatively, infection-driven inflammation can 176 disturb neuronal function and cause long-term deficits. 33,72-74 Dysregulation of inflammatory 177 responses may cause brain dysfunction and behavioral alterations via multiple mechanisms. 33,75,76 178 Microglia are the primary neuroimmune cells and perform vital functions in brain 179 homeostasis and defense against pathogens, but they can also contribute to disease processes 180 (reviewed in 77,78 ). In response to infection, microglia increase in number, migrate to the primary 181 site of infection and acquire an activated phagocytic phenotype associated with pro-inflammatory 182 cytokine release. 73,74,77,79 Microglia contribute to memory deficits in mouse models of CNS viral 183 infection by actively attacking and eliminating synapses. 33,72 Once activated, microglia may 184 respond with greater sensitivity to subsequent stimuli (a mechanism known as priming), resulting 185 in exaggerated inflammatory responses and increasing susceptibility to neurodegenerative 186 processes. 73,74 187 Astrocytes are an essential component of the neurovascular unit and provide a link between 188 neurons and blood vessels. In homeostasis, astrocytes support and maintain BBB integrity, C1q) induce a functional shift of astrocytes to the so-called A1 phenotype, a subtype of astrocytes 194 that lose their physiological roles in neuronal and synaptic maintenance. 82 A1 astrocytes are 195 observed in CNS diseases and injuries, and trigger neuronal and oligodendrocyte loss. 82,83 196 Astrocytes are involved with both acute and chronic neurological effects, as well as long-term 197 sequelae in neuro-infectious diseases, as several viruses can infect and activate astrocytes, altering 198 BBB permeability and neuronal function (reviewed in 84 ). 199 As a consequence of infection or other injuries, monocytes differentiate into macrophages 200 recruited to affected tissues. 85 In the CNS, macrophages are present at perivascular spaces, 201 meninges, and the choroid plexus, where they act as scavengers and physiological modulators. 78 202 While macrophages are critical for innate immune response, T-lymphocytes are the primary 203 effectors of adaptive immunity. T-lymphocytes also play a role in the CNS, patrolling the 204 meningeal spaces and contributing to normal behavior and cognition. In CNS infections, 205 macrophages and lymphocytes infiltrate the brain parenchyma and contribute to local cytokine 206 release. 75,76,86 207 Cytokines play important roles in synaptic plasticity and neuronal physiology 87-94 , but 208 aberrant upregulation of cytokine production and secretion in the CNS interferes with neuronal 209 function and with neurotransmitter-mediated pathways. 75 As aforementioned, COVID-19 patients 210 experience a hyper-inflammatory syndrome, with increased circulating levels of several cytokines, 211 including TNF-⍺ and interleukin-6 (IL-6). 18-20 TNF-α is a homotrimer that signals through TNF of synaptic connectivity. 87 However, upregulation of brain TNF-α impairs synaptic 216 plasticity, motor control, memory and induces microglial and astrocyte activation. 33,34,88-90 217 Under physiological conditions, IL-6 is present at low levels in the brain and has known 218 roles in neurogenesis, gliogenesis, and regeneration of peripheral nerves (for a review, see 97 ). IL-219 6 signaling requires two co-receptors, the IL-6-binding receptor (IL-6R) and the signal-transducing 220 protein, glycoprotein 130 (gp130). Classical IL-6 signaling involves binding IL-6 to IL-6R 221 followed by activation of gp130 and recruitment of Janus kinase (JAK) to initiate intracellular 222 signaling. 97,98 Interestingly, neurons do not appear to express relevant amounts of the membrane-223 bound IL-6R isoform; instead, they express a soluble isoform of the receptor (sIL-6R) 99 , which 224 binds circulating IL-6 and activates membrane-bound gp130. This process, known as trans-225 signaling 97,98 , has been implicated in cognitive dysfunction caused by lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in 226 aged mice. 100 227 2285. Inflammation as a potential driver of cognitive decline and depressive symptoms in COVID-229 19 230 Delirium and encephalopathy are commonly reported in COVID-19 hospitalized patients; 231 however, estimates of the incidence of delirium and encephalopathy diverge largely among 232 different cohorts. 10,101,102 A retrospective cohort study of electronic health records of 236,379 233 COVID-19 survivors found that one-third of the patients developed neurological or psychiatric 234 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f conditions within six months of infection. 103,104 Those rates were higher in severe COVID-19 cases 235 (e.g., individuals admitted to intensive care units) and were higher for SARS-CoV-2 than for 236 influenza infections. Post-mortem analysis of COVID-19 patient brains revealed local 237 inflammation, microglial activation, immune cell infiltration, signs of hypoxia, infarcts, and 238 microvascular damage. 12,53,68-70 Additionally, COVID-19 patients show elevated blood and CSF 239 biomarkers of inflammation, neuronal damage, and astrocytic activation, associated with 240 neurological symptoms and disease severity. 105-108 Molecular and metabolic changes triggered by 241 hypoxia and inflammation may induce encephalopathy and long-term neurological dysfunction 242 independently of CNS infection in critically ill patients. 109-111 Considering that recent findings do 243 not support the presence of SARS-CoV-2 viral material in the brain as the primary source of 244 COVID-19 neuroinflammation 68,69 , an alternative hypothesis implicates systemic factors as 245 mediators of CNS pathology. 246 IL-6 and TNF-⍺ are critical mediators of the inflammatory response in COVID-19. Blood 247 levels of IL-6 predict disease progression and correlate with COVID-19 severity and 248 mortality. 112,113 Blood TNF-α is high in critically ill COVID-19 patients. 113 Evidence supporting 249 the involvement of IL-6 and TNF-⍺ in the progression of COVID-19 has led to ongoing research 250 aimed at inhibiting these cytokines as acute treatment options for severe disease cases. 114-116 In 251 August 2021, the WHO announced a clinical trial to test three COVID-19 candidate drugs. One of 252 them was Infliximab, a monoclonal antibody that blocks TNF-α signaling 117 and found to alleviate 253 cognitive deficits in mouse models of brain infection by Zika virus 33 and of Alzheimer's disease 254 (AD). 24 255 While microglia and macrophages express ACE2, this protein is not abundantly expressed 256 in most blood-derived immune cells 118 , suggesting that other receptors, including toll-like 257 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f receptors (TLRs), might be involved in the inflammatory response to SARS-CoV-2. Significantly, the persistence of depressive symptoms was associated with 271 systemic inflammation biomarkers during acute infection and in the follow-up visit. 13 272 Inflammation is a point of convergence between neurodegenerative diseases and mood 273 disorders, particularly major depressive disorder (MDD). 124,125 MDD patients have upregulation 274 of inflammatory pathways 126 , and psychosocial stress can increase inflammatory response. 127,128 275 Investigation of the impact of inflammation on brain circuits involved in mood control has 276 elucidated processes underlying resistance to conventional anti-depressants 126 , and has inspired 277 clinical trials using anti-inflammatory strategies to treat subgroups of depressive patients. 129 In 278 animals, infections induce a stereotyped and conserved "sickness behavior", characterized by 279 lethargy, anorexia, anhedonia, and depressive-like behavior 130 , which has been shown to result 280 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f from elevated circulating cytokines. 75,131 Although it is challenging to mimic the complexity of 281 depression in rodents, work with animal models has helped increase our understanding of the role 282 of pro-inflammatory molecules in MDD. 131-133 For example, intracranial administration of IL-6 or 283 TNF-⍺ triggers depressive-like behavior in mice 134,135 , and TNF-⍺ blockade rescued memory 284 impairment in a stress-induced rat model of depression. 136 285 Inflammation is also thought to be a fundamental component of neurodegenerative 286 processes. 137,138 Plasma TNF-⍺ and soluble TNF-α receptors are typically reported as upregulated 287 in severe AD cases 139-145 , and elevated production of TNF-⍺ by peripheral blood mononuclear 288 cells is associated with an increased risk of developing AD. 146 Circulating IL-6 levels are elevated 289 in AD patients 145,147 , predict cognitive decline later in life 148 , and show a negative correlation with 290 memory scores. 145,147 In vivo and in vitro studies show that both cytokines trigger stress response 291 mechanisms and disrupt synaptic plasticity, memory formation, and hippocampal 292 neurogenesis. 149-151 In mouse models of AD, blockage of TNF-α and IL-6 signaling pathways 293 rescues memory. 24,147,152 Collectively, data indicate that aberrant signaling by TNF-α and IL-6 294 disturbs memory-related mechanisms and promotes cognitive decline. 295 Systemic inflammation associated with infections contributes to persistent molecular 296 alterations and functional deficits in the CNS. Sepsis survivors frequently experience neurological 297 sequelae and present an increased risk for developing dementia. 153,154 In mice, sepsis enhances 298 brain amyloid pathology, induces brain metabolic changes and TNF-⍺ upregulation, analogous to 299 what is found in animal models of AD. 22,73,74,155 Furthermore, sepsis-surviving mice exhibit 300 increased susceptibility to toxicity induced by soluble Aβ oligomers, with excessive 301 neuroinflammatory responses and IL-6 upregulation. 73,74 Aberrant microglial activation appears to 302 play a central role in sepsis-induced late cognitive impairment. 73,74 Similarly, infection by ZIKV 303 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f induces synapse damage and persistent memory deficits via microglia-mediated synapse 304 engulfment and elimination. 33 ZIKV infection also induces upregulation of TNF-α, which, in this 305case, appears to be upstream of microglial activation. Importantly, blockage of TNF-α signaling 306 rescues acute and persistent brain pathology, as well as synaptic plasticity and memory in ZIKV-307 infected mice.33,34    308

Although viral particles and RNA have not been detected 325 consistently in CSF and brain tissue from patients 67-70 , SARS-CoV-2 spike protein was found to 326 cross the BBB in a rodent model, and to induce functional changes in an in vitro model, possibly 327 via a pro-inflammatory response from endothelial cells. 62,165 Consistent with this finding, 328 CSF/serum albumin ratio measurement revealed BBB dysfunction in 40% of the individuals in a 329 French cohort of COVID-19 patients with neurological manifestations. 166 On the other hand, 330 elevated inflammatory markers in the CSF are verified only in a subset of COVID-19 patients with 331 neurological symptoms, and are independent of circulating cytokine levels. the neurological consequences of COVID-19 poses several challenges. First, 335 substantial variability is observed regarding the types and frequencies of neurological symptoms. 336 Moreover, the biological impact of COVID-19 on mental health may be confounded by adverse 337 effects associated with social isolation, job/financial insecurity, and other social impacts of the 338 pandemic. From a molecular/cellular standpoint, post-mortem brain analysis is generally limited 339 to severe cases of COVID-19, and pathogenic mechanisms revealed in such studies may differ 340 significantly from mechanisms operating in the brains of COVID-19 survivors. As the COVID-19 341 pandemic continues to ravage the world in its third year, leaving an unprecedented number of 342 infected survivors, possible late neurological outcomes pose a significant future threat to patients 343 and public health systems.
